stream_context.summary: Kaze models and plans a craft-themed level: tunes a pseudo-normal-mapped styrofoam mountain shader, lays out missions (carry-a-crayon, paper-plane ride, pyramid red-coins, rolling-crayon log, etc.), experiments with paper-plate mushroom umbrellas and popsicle-stick bridges, brainstorms new cardboard enemies, and finally pivots the planned ice zone to a castle biome.

development_findings.summary: Implemented a CPU-generated pseudo normal/bump mapping system so styrofoam blocks reflect light dynamically despite the N64’s lack of native support.
development_findings.quote: The N64 does not have normal map support. I added the support. The texture is computed on the CPU and then the GPU just has to render it.

development_findings.summary: Current shader still uses camera angle for reflections; Kaze plans to incorporate true light direction and may add 8-12 orientation textures to improve accuracy.
Cannot use advanced F3DEX3 features because major emulators don’t support them, so effects must stay within older microcodes.
development_findings.quote: The problem with the F3DEX3 stuff is that emulators haven't gotten there yet, so if I do F3DEX3 stuff our stuff is not going to run on emulator.

development_findings.summary: Star 1 flow set: tilt-bridge to Luigi doodle, escort a yellow crayon past enemies, draw star.
Sandy dune section: rubber-band or paper-spring launcher to googly-eyed swamps leading to pyramid interior for red coins.
Paper plane on elastic path will carry player, revealing an 8-bit pipe and awarding silver-star mission.
Planned hazards: rolling crayon log, cardboard saw blades, unbeatable scissor enemy, falling cardboard bridges that spring back, cardboard Womps/Thwomps/Bombs.
Course relies on simple craft materials (styrofoam, felt palms, paper plates, popsicle sticks) which speeds up modeling.
development_findings.quote: This course was really fast to do because it's made out of simple craft materials.

development_findings.summary: Design pivot: abandoned snow/ice idea after difficulty representing it; area will now become a castle biome.
development_findings.quote: Maybe ice just doesn't work… I think I'm changing this to a castle biome.

development_findings.summary: Introduced 2D cardboard ‘doodle’ characters (Yoshi, Luigi, Toad) rigged with simple bones for waving animations.
High-poly ideas like cotton-ball snow or sugar-cube ice discarded for performance; five-vertex crayons and low-triangle popsicle sticks used instead.
Texture workflow favors multi-texturing over decals to cut draw-calls; constant online texture hunting is part of process.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prioritizes convincing material cues: "whole point is to have the lighting bounce off it dynamically."
context_findings.quote: The whole point of this is to be able to have the lighting bounce of it dynamically so it fits what the camera would see.

context_findings.summary: Actively incorporates chat feedback (e.g., styrofoam color, mushroom look) and is comfortable pivoting designs in real-time.
Shows frustration with new Blender version and tech hurdles but excitement when assets look right ("Look how sexy these plates look").
Acknowledges donations and budgets light-heartedly ("$50 is like 10 burgers at least").

biobak.summary: Assisting by reworking some of Kaze’s levels.

badub.summary: Composing most of the game’s music; chat requests specific OST tracks during stream.

zeina.summary: Currently working on the overworld; provides personal feedback and casually appears in stream banter.

key_stories.title: Bringing Normal Maps to N64
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants styrofoam mountains to shimmer realistically, so he writes a CPU routine that bakes directional normal textures for the N64’s limited GPU. Chat critiques the math and lighting, prompting tweaks.
key_stories.challenge: N64 lacks normal-map support, making reflective craft materials hard to sell.
key_stories.process: Generates textures per face orientation, multiplies normals by camera vector, and debates switching to true light vector or more angles.
key_stories.outcome: Effect works but still needs angle refinements and smoothing; demonstrates Kaze’s technical ingenuity.
key_stories.key_quote: The N64 does not have normal map support. I added the support.

key_stories.title: Goodbye Ice, Hello Castle
key_stories.summary: An ice biome was planned for the level’s final stretch, but craftable snow proved too high-poly and visually weak. After experimenting with cotton balls, sugar cubes, and paper-mâché, Kaze decides to scrap it in favor of a castle made of craft supplies.
key_stories.challenge: Couldn’t find a performant yet convincing way to depict snow/ice with craft materials.
key_stories.process: Explored cotton-ball snow, sugar-cube blocks, paper-mâché, and volcano alternatives; reviewed reference dioramas.
key_stories.outcome: Ice section removed; area will now be a cardboard castle with new hazards and cannon transport.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe ice just doesn't work… I think I'm changing this to a castle biome.

key_stories.title: The Yellow Crayon Escort
key_stories.summary: To earn one star, players must ferry a yellow crayon across hazards to help a Luigi doodle finish drawing a star.
key_stories.challenge: Design a mission that emphasizes the craft theme and varied platforming.
key_stories.process: Added wooden crayon pick-up, tilting bridge, enemy gauntlet, and doodle dialog.
key_stories.outcome: Mission structure finalized; enemy placement and scripting still pending.
key_stories.key_quote: The Luigi doodle is gonna be like I need a yellow crayon to finish my star… and you bring it to the doodle and then you draw the star.
